Fluoride is a naturally occurring mineral that is found in water, soil, and various foods. It is known for its ability to strengthen tooth enamel and prevent tooth decay by making teeth more resistant to acid attacks from bacteria in the mouth. When fluoride is ingested, especially during childhood when teeth are developing, it can be incorporated into the structure of the teeth, making them stronger and less prone to cavities.

Fluoride is added to public water supplies in a carefully controlled amount—typically around 0.7 milligrams per liter—as part of a public health measure to reduce dental caries (cavities) in the population. This practice, known as water fluoridation, has been in place in many countries since the mid-20th century and is supported by numerous health organizations, including the World Health Organization (WHO), the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and the American Dental Association (ADA).

The scientific consensus is that optimally fluoridated water is a safe and effective way to improve dental health, particularly among children and low-income populations who may have limited access to dental care. It is one of the most cost-effective public health interventions available for preventing tooth decay.

Water fluoridation is not about medicating the population, but about providing a community-wide preventive health benefit through a naturally occurring mineral at levels that have been shown to be safe and effective.
